iam.update-login-profile: Changes the password for the specified IAM user. You can use the AWS CLI, the AWS API, or the Users page in the IAM console to change the password for any IAM user. Use  ChangePassword to change your own password in the My Security Credentials page in the AWS Management Console.
iam.update-open-id-connect-provider-thumbpri: Replaces the existing list of server certificate thumbprints associated with an OpenID Connect (OIDC) provider resource object with a new list of thumbprints.
iam.update-role: Updates the description or maximum session duration setting of a role.
iam.update-saml-provider: Updates the metadata document for an existing SAML provider resource object.
iam.update-server-certificate: Updates the name and/or the path of the specified server certificate stored in IAM.
iam.update-service-specific-credential: Sets the status of a service-specific credential to Active or Inactive . Service-specific credentials that are inactive cannot be used for authentication to the service. This operation can be used to disable a user's service-specific credential as part of a credential rotation work flow.
iam.update-signing-certificate: Changes the status of the specified user signing certificate from active to disabled, or vice versa. This operation can be used to disable an IAM user's signing certificate as part of a certificate rotation work flow.
iam.update-ssh-public-key: Sets the status of an IAM user's SSH public key to active or inactive. SSH public keys that are inactive cannot be used for authentication. This operation can be used to disable a user's SSH public key as part of a key rotation work flow.
iam.update-user: Updates the name and/or the path of the specified IAM user.
iam.upload-server-certificate: Uploads a server certificate entity for the AWS account. The server certificate entity includes a public key certificate, a private key, and an optional certificate chain, which should all be PEM-encoded.
iam.upload-signing-certificate: Uploads an X.509 signing certificate and associates it with the specified IAM user. Some AWS services require you to use certificates to validate requests that are signed with a corresponding private key. When you upload the certificate, its default status is Active .
iam.upload-ssh-public-key: Uploads an SSH public key and associates it with the specified IAM user.
iam.wait instance-profile-exists: Wait until 200 response is received when polling with get-instance-profile. It will poll every 1 seconds until a successful state has been reached. This will exit with a return code of 255 after 40 failed checks.
iam.wait policy-exists: Wait until 200 response is received when polling with get-policy. It will poll every 1 seconds until a successful state has been reached. This will exit with a return code of 255 after 20 failed checks.
iam.wait role-exists: Wait until 200 response is received when polling with get-role. It will poll every 1 seconds until a successful state has been reached. This will exit with a return code of 255 after 20 failed checks.
iam.wait user-exists: Wait until 200 response is received when polling with get-user. It will poll every 1 seconds until a successful state has been reached. This will exit with a return code of 255 after 20 failed checks.

identitystore.describe-group: Retrieves the group metadata and attributes from GroupId in an identity store.
identitystore.describe-user: Retrieves the user metadata and attributes from UserId in an identity store.
identitystore.list-groups: Lists the attribute name and value of the group that you specified in the search. We only support DisplayName as a valid filter attribute path currently, and filter is required. This API returns minimum attributes, including GroupId and group DisplayName in the response.
identitystore.list-users: Lists the attribute name and value of the user that you specified in the search. We only support UserName as a valid filter attribute path currently, and filter is required. This API returns minimum attributes, including UserId and UserName in the response.

imagebuilder.cancel-image-creation: CancelImageCreation cancels the creation of Image. This operation can only be used on images in a non-terminal state.
imagebuilder.create-component: Creates a new component that can be used to build, validate, test, and assess your image.
imagebuilder.create-container-recipe: Creates a new container recipe. Container recipes define how images are configured, tested, and assessed.
imagebuilder.create-distribution-configuration: Creates a new distribution configuration. Distribution configurations define and configure the outputs of your pipeline.
imagebuilder.create-image: Creates a new image. This request will create a new image along with all of the configured output resources defined in the distribution configuration.
imagebuilder.create-image-pipeline: Creates a new image pipeline. Image pipelines enable you to automate the creation and distribution of images.
imagebuilder.create-image-recipe: Creates a new image recipe. Image recipes define how images are configured, tested, and assessed.
imagebuilder.create-infrastructure-configuration: Creates a new infrastructure configuration. An infrastructure configuration defines the environment in which your image will be built and tested.
imagebuilder.get-container-recipe-policy: Retrieves the policy for a container recipe.
imagebuilder.import-component: Imports a component and transforms its data into a component document.
imagebuilder.list-component-build-versions: Returns the list of component build versions for the specified semantic version.
imagebuilder.list-components: Returns the list of component build versions for the specified semantic version.
imagebuilder.list-container-recipes: Returns a list of container recipes.
imagebuilder.list-distribution-configurations: Returns a list of distribution configurations.
imagebuilder.list-image-build-versions: Returns a list of image build versions.
imagebuilder.list-image-packages: List the Packages that are associated with an Image Build Version, as determined by AWS Systems Manager Inventory at build time.
imagebuilder.list-image-pipeline-images: Returns a list of images created by the specified pipeline.
imagebuilder.list-image-pipelines: Returns a list of image pipelines.
imagebuilder.list-image-recipes: Returns a list of image recipes.
imagebuilder.list-images: Returns the list of images that you have access to.
imagebuilder.list-infrastructure-configurations: Returns a list of infrastructure configurations.
imagebuilder.list-tags-for-resource: Returns the list of tags for the specified resource.
imagebuilder.put-component-policy: Applies a policy to a component. We recommend that you call the RAM API CreateResourceShare to share resources. If you call the Image Builder API PutComponentPolicy , you must also call the RAM API PromoteResourceShareCreatedFromPolicy in order for the resource to be visible to all principals with whom the resource is shared.
imagebuilder.put-container-recipe-policy: Applies a policy to a container image. We recommend that you call the RAM API CreateResourceShare (https://docs.aws.amazon.com/ram/latest/APIReference/API_CreateResourceShare.html) to share resources. If you call the Image Builder API PutContainerImagePolicy , you must also call the RAM API PromoteResourceShareCreatedFromPolicy (https://docs.aws.amazon.com/ram/latest/APIReference/API_PromoteResourceShareCreatedFromPolicy.html) in order for the resource to be visible to all principals with whom the resource is shared.
imagebuilder.put-image-policy: Applies a policy to an image. We recommend that you call the RAM API CreateResourceShare to share resources. If you call the Image Builder API PutImagePolicy , you must also call the RAM API PromoteResourceShareCreatedFromPolicy in order for the resource to be visible to all principals with whom the resource is shared.
imagebuilder.put-image-recipe-policy: Applies a policy to an image recipe. We recommend that you call the RAM API CreateResourceShare to share resources. If you call the Image Builder API PutImageRecipePolicy , you must also call the RAM API PromoteResourceShareCreatedFromPolicy in order for the resource to be visible to all principals with whom the resource is shared.
imagebuilder.start-image-pipeline-execution: Manually triggers a pipeline to create an image.
imagebuilder.tag-resource: Adds a tag to a resource.
imagebuilder.untag-resource: Removes a tag from a resource.
imagebuilder.update-distribution-configuration: Updates a new distribution configuration. Distribution configurations define and configure the outputs of your pipeline.
imagebuilder.update-image-pipeline: Updates a new image pipeline. Image pipelines enable you to automate the creation and distribution of images.
imagebuilder.update-infrastructure-configuration: Updates a new infrastructure configuration. An infrastructure configuration defines the environment in which your image will be built and tested.

importexport.cancel-job: This operation cancels a specified job. Only the job owner can cancel it. The operation fails if the job has already started or is complete.
importexport.create-job: This operation initiates the process of scheduling an upload or download of your data. You include in the request a manifest that describes the data transfer specifics. The response to the request includes a job ID, which you can use in other operations, a signature that you use to identify your storage device, and the address where you should ship your storage device.
importexport.get-shipping-label: This operation generates a pre-paid UPS shipping label that you will use to ship your device to AWS for processing.
importexport.get-status: This operation returns information about a job, including where the job is in the processing pipeline, the status of the results, and the signature value associated with the job. You can only return information about jobs you own.
importexport.list-jobs: This operation returns the jobs associated with the requester. AWS Import/Export lists the jobs in reverse chronological order based on the date of creation. For example if Job Test1 was created 2009Dec30 and Test2 was created 2010Feb05, the ListJobs operation would return Test2 followed by Test1.
importexport.update-job: You use this operation to change the parameters specified in the original manifest file by supplying a new manifest file. The manifest file attached to this request replaces the original manifest file. You can only use the operation after a CreateJob request but before the data transfer starts and you can only use it on jobs you own.

inspector.add-attributes-to-findings: Assigns attributes (key and value pairs) to the findings that are specified by the ARNs of the findings.
inspector.create-assessment-target: Creates a new assessment target using the ARN of the resource group that is generated by  CreateResourceGroup . If resourceGroupArn is not specified, all EC2 instances in the current AWS account and region are included in the assessment target. If the service-linked role isn’t already registered, this action also creates and registers a service-linked role to grant Amazon Inspector access to AWS Services needed to perform security assessments. You can create up to 50 assessment targets per AWS account. You can run up to 500 concurrent agents per AWS account. For more information, see Amazon Inspector Assessment Targets .
inspector.create-assessment-template: Creates an assessment template for the assessment target that is specified by the ARN of the assessment target. If the service-linked role isn’t already registered, this action also creates and registers a service-linked role to grant Amazon Inspector access to AWS Services needed to perform security assessments.
inspector.create-exclusions-preview: Starts the generation of an exclusions preview for the specified assessment template. The exclusions preview lists the potential exclusions (ExclusionPreview) that Inspector can detect before it runs the assessment.
inspector.create-resource-group: Creates a resource group using the specified set of tags (key and value pairs) that are used to select the EC2 instances to be included in an Amazon Inspector assessment target. The created resource group is then used to create an Amazon Inspector assessment target. For more information, see  CreateAssessmentTarget .
inspector.delete-assessment-run: Deletes the assessment run that is specified by the ARN of the assessment run.
inspector.delete-assessment-target: Deletes the assessment target that is specified by the ARN of the assessment target.
inspector.delete-assessment-template: Deletes the assessment template that is specified by the ARN of the assessment template.
inspector.describe-assessment-runs: Describes the assessment runs that are specified by the ARNs of the assessment runs.
inspector.describe-assessment-targets: Describes the assessment targets that are specified by the ARNs of the assessment targets.
inspector.describe-assessment-templates: Describes the assessment templates that are specified by the ARNs of the assessment templates.
inspector.describe-cross-account-access-role: Describes the IAM role that enables Amazon Inspector to access your AWS account.
inspector.describe-exclusions: Describes the exclusions that are specified by the exclusions' ARNs.
inspector.describe-findings: Describes the findings that are specified by the ARNs of the findings.
inspector.describe-resource-groups: Describes the resource groups that are specified by the ARNs of the resource groups.
inspector.describe-rules-packages: Describes the rules packages that are specified by the ARNs of the rules packages.
inspector.get-assessment-report: Produces an assessment report that includes detailed and comprehensive results of a specified assessment run.
inspector.get-exclusions-preview: Retrieves the exclusions preview (a list of ExclusionPreview objects) specified by the preview token. You can obtain the preview token by running the CreateExclusionsPreview API.
inspector.get-telemetry-metadata: Information about the data that is collected for the specified assessment run.
inspector.list-assessment-run-agents: Lists the agents of the assessment runs that are specified by the ARNs of the assessment runs.
inspector.list-assessment-runs: Lists the assessment runs that correspond to the assessment templates that are specified by the ARNs of the assessment templates.
inspector.list-assessment-targets: Lists the ARNs of the assessment targets within this AWS account. For more information about assessment targets, see Amazon Inspector Assessment Targets .
inspector.list-assessment-templates: Lists the assessment templates that correspond to the assessment targets that are specified by the ARNs of the assessment targets.
inspector.list-event-subscriptions: Lists all the event subscriptions for the assessment template that is specified by the ARN of the assessment template. For more information, see  SubscribeToEvent and  UnsubscribeFromEvent .
inspector.list-exclusions: List exclusions that are generated by the assessment run.
inspector.list-findings: Lists findings that are generated by the assessment runs that are specified by the ARNs of the assessment runs.
inspector.list-rules-packages: Lists all available Amazon Inspector rules packages.
inspector.list-tags-for-resource: Lists all tags associated with an assessment template.
inspector.preview-agents: Previews the agents installed on the EC2 instances that are part of the specified assessment target.
inspector.register-cross-account-access-role: Registers the IAM role that grants Amazon Inspector access to AWS Services needed to perform security assessments.
inspector.remove-attributes-from-findings: Removes entire attributes (key and value pairs) from the findings that are specified by the ARNs of the findings where an attribute with the specified key exists.
inspector.set-tags-for-resource: Sets tags (key and value pairs) to the assessment template that is specified by the ARN of the assessment template.
inspector.start-assessment-run: Starts the assessment run specified by the ARN of the assessment template. For this API to function properly, you must not exceed the limit of running up to 500 concurrent agents per AWS account.
inspector.stop-assessment-run: Stops the assessment run that is specified by the ARN of the assessment run.
inspector.subscribe-to-event: Enables the process of sending Amazon Simple Notification Service (SNS) notifications about a specified event to a specified SNS topic.
inspector.unsubscribe-from-event: Disables the process of sending Amazon Simple Notification Service (SNS) notifications about a specified event to a specified SNS topic.
inspector.update-assessment-target: Updates the assessment target that is specified by the ARN of the assessment target.

iot.accept-certificate-transfer: Accepts a pending certificate transfer. The default state of the certificate is INACTIVE.
iot.add-thing-to-billing-group: Adds a thing to a billing group.
iot.add-thing-to-thing-group: Adds a thing to a thing group.
iot.associate-targets-with-job: Associates a group with a continuous job. The following criteria must be met:
iot.attach-policy: Attaches a policy to the specified target.
iot.attach-principal-policy: Attaches the specified policy to the specified principal (certificate or other credential).
iot.attach-security-profile: Associates a Device Defender security profile with a thing group or this account. Each thing group or account can have up to five security profiles associated with it.
iot.attach-thing-principal: Attaches the specified principal to the specified thing. A principal can be X.509 certificates, IAM users, groups, and roles, Amazon Cognito identities or federated identities.
iot.cancel-audit-mitigation-actions-task: Cancels a mitigation action task that is in progress. If the task is not in progress, an InvalidRequestException occurs.
iot.cancel-audit-task: Cancels an audit that is in progress. The audit can be either scheduled or on demand. If the audit isn't in progress, an "InvalidRequestException" occurs.
iot.cancel-certificate-transfer: Cancels a pending transfer for the specified certificate.
iot.cancel-detect-mitigation-actions-task: Cancels a Device Defender ML Detect mitigation action.
iot.cancel-job-execution: Cancels the execution of a job for a given thing.
iot.confirm-topic-rule-destination: Confirms a topic rule destination. When you create a rule requiring a destination, AWS IoT sends a confirmation message to the endpoint or base address you specify. The message includes a token which you pass back when calling ConfirmTopicRuleDestination to confirm that you own or have access to the endpoint.
iot.create-audit-suppression: Creates a Device Defender audit suppression.
iot.create-certificate-from-csr: Creates an X.509 certificate using the specified certificate signing request.
iot.create-custom-metric: Use this API to define a Custom Metric published by your devices to Device Defender.
iot.create-dimension: Create a dimension that you can use to limit the scope of a metric used in a security profile for AWS IoT Device Defender. For example, using a TOPIC_FILTER dimension, you can narrow down the scope of the metric only to MQTT topics whose name match the pattern specified in the dimension.
iot.create-keys-and-certificate: Creates a 2048-bit RSA key pair and issues an X.509 certificate using the issued public key. You can also call CreateKeysAndCertificate over MQTT from a device, for more information, see Provisioning MQTT API .
iot.create-mitigation-action: Defines an action that can be applied to audit findings by using StartAuditMitigationActionsTask. Only certain types of mitigation actions can be applied to specific check names. For more information, see Mitigation actions . Each mitigation action can apply only one type of change.
iot.create-ota-update: Creates an AWS IoT OTAUpdate on a target group of things or groups.
iot.create-policy-version: Creates a new version of the specified AWS IoT policy. To update a policy, create a new policy version. A managed policy can have up to five versions. If the policy has five versions, you must use  DeletePolicyVersion to delete an existing version before you create a new one.
iot.create-provisioning-template-version: Creates a new version of a fleet provisioning template.
iot.create-scheduled-audit: Creates a scheduled audit that is run at a specified time interval.
iot.create-security-profile: Creates a Device Defender security profile.
iot.create-stream: Creates a stream for delivering one or more large files in chunks over MQTT. A stream transports data bytes in chunks or blocks packaged as MQTT messages from a source like S3. You can have one or more files associated with a stream.
iot.create-thing: Creates a thing record in the registry. If this call is made multiple times using the same thing name and configuration, the call will succeed. If this call is made with the same thing name but different configuration a ResourceAlreadyExistsException is thrown.
iot.create-topic-rule: Creates a rule. Creating rules is an administrator-level action. Any user who has permission to create rules will be able to access data processed by the rule.
iot.create-topic-rule-destination: Creates a topic rule destination. The destination must be confirmed prior to use.
iot.delete-account-audit-configuration: Restores the default settings for Device Defender audits for this account. Any configuration data you entered is deleted and all audit checks are reset to disabled.
iot.delete-audit-suppression: Deletes a Device Defender audit suppression.
iot.delete-dimension: Removes the specified dimension from your AWS account.
iot.delete-job: Deletes a job and its related job executions.
iot.delete-mitigation-action: Deletes a defined mitigation action from your AWS account.
iot.delete-policy-version: Deletes the specified version of the specified policy. You cannot delete the default version of a policy using this API. To delete the default version of a policy, use  DeletePolicy . To find out which version of a policy is marked as the default version, use ListPolicyVersions.
iot.delete-provisioning-template-version: Deletes a fleet provisioning template version.
iot.delete-registration-code: Deletes a CA certificate registration code.
iot.delete-security-profile: Deletes a Device Defender security profile.
iot.delete-thing: Deletes the specified thing. Returns successfully with no error if the deletion is successful or you specify a thing that doesn't exist.
iot.delete-thing-type: Deletes the specified thing type. You cannot delete a thing type if it has things associated with it. To delete a thing type, first mark it as deprecated by calling  DeprecateThingType , then remove any associated things by calling  UpdateThing to change the thing type on any associated thing, and finally use  DeleteThingType to delete the thing type.
iot.deprecate-thing-type: Deprecates a thing type. You can not associate new things with deprecated thing type.
iot.describe-account-audit-configuration: Gets information about the Device Defender audit settings for this account. Settings include how audit notifications are sent and which audit checks are enabled or disabled.
iot.describe-audit-finding: Gets information about a single audit finding. Properties include the reason for noncompliance, the severity of the issue, and the start time when the audit that returned the finding.
iot.describe-audit-mitigation-actions-task: Gets information about an audit mitigation task that is used to apply mitigation actions to a set of audit findings. Properties include the actions being applied, the audit checks to which they're being applied, the task status, and aggregated task statistics.
iot.describe-audit-suppression: Gets information about a Device Defender audit suppression.
iot.describe-audit-task: Gets information about a Device Defender audit.
iot.describe-billing-group: Returns information about a billing group.
iot.describe-certificate: Gets information about the specified certificate.
iot.describe-custom-metric: Gets information about a Device Defender detect custom metric.
iot.describe-detect-mitigation-actions-task: Gets information about a Device Defender ML Detect mitigation action.
iot.describe-dimension: Provides details about a dimension that is defined in your AWS account.
iot.describe-domain-configuration: Gets summary information about a domain configuration.
iot.describe-endpoint: Returns a unique endpoint specific to the AWS account making the call.
iot.describe-mitigation-action: Gets information about a mitigation action.
iot.describe-provisioning-template: Returns information about a fleet provisioning template.
iot.describe-provisioning-template-version: Returns information about a fleet provisioning template version.
iot.describe-scheduled-audit: Gets information about a scheduled audit.
iot.describe-security-profile: Gets information about a Device Defender security profile.
iot.describe-thing: Gets information about the specified thing.
iot.describe-thing-registration-task: Describes a bulk thing provisioning task.
iot.describe-thing-type: Gets information about the specified thing type.
iot.detach-policy: Detaches a policy from the specified target.
iot.detach-principal-policy: Removes the specified policy from the specified certificate.
iot.detach-security-profile: Disassociates a Device Defender security profile from a thing group or from this account.
iot.detach-thing-principal: Detaches the specified principal from the specified thing. A principal can be X.509 certificates, IAM users, groups, and roles, Amazon Cognito identities or federated identities.
iot.get-behavior-model-training-summaries: Returns a Device Defender's ML Detect Security Profile training model's status.
iot.get-cardinality: Returns the approximate count of unique values that match the query.
iot.get-effective-policies: Gets a list of the policies that have an effect on the authorization behavior of the specified device when it connects to the AWS IoT device gateway.
iot.get-percentiles: Groups the aggregated values that match the query into percentile groupings. The default percentile groupings are: 1,5,25,50,75,95,99, although you can specify your own when you call GetPercentiles . This function returns a value for each percentile group specified (or the default percentile groupings). The percentile group "1" contains the aggregated field value that occurs in approximately one percent of the values that match the query. The percentile group "5" contains the aggregated field value that occurs in approximately five percent of the values that match the query, and so on. The result is an approximation, the more values that match the query, the more accurate the percentile values.
iot.get-policy: Gets information about the specified policy with the policy document of the default version.
iot.get-policy-version: Gets information about the specified policy version.
iot.get-registration-code: Gets a registration code used to register a CA certificate with AWS IoT.
iot.get-statistics: Returns the count, average, sum, minimum, maximum, sum of squares, variance, and standard deviation for the specified aggregated field. If the aggregation field is of type String , only the count statistic is returned.
iot.get-topic-rule-destination: Gets information about a topic rule destination.
iot.get-v2-logging-options: Gets the fine grained logging options.
iot.list-active-violations: Lists the active violations for a given Device Defender security profile.
iot.list-attached-policies: Lists the policies attached to the specified thing group.
iot.list-audit-findings: Lists the findings (results) of a Device Defender audit or of the audits performed during a specified time period. (Findings are retained for 90 days.)
iot.list-audit-mitigation-actions-executions: Gets the status of audit mitigation action tasks that were executed.
iot.list-audit-mitigation-actions-tasks: Gets a list of audit mitigation action tasks that match the specified filters.
iot.list-audit-suppressions: Lists your Device Defender audit listings.
iot.list-audit-tasks: Lists the Device Defender audits that have been performed during a given time period.
iot.list-authorizers: Lists the authorizers registered in your account.
iot.list-billing-groups: Lists the billing groups you have created.
iot.list-ca-certificates: Lists the CA certificates registered for your AWS account.
iot.list-certificates: Lists the certificates registered in your AWS account.
iot.list-certificates-by-ca: List the device certificates signed by the specified CA certificate.
iot.list-custom-metrics: Lists your Device Defender detect custom metrics.
iot.list-detect-mitigation-actions-execution: Lists mitigation actions executions for a Device Defender ML Detect Security Profile.
iot.list-detect-mitigation-actions-tasks: List of Device Defender ML Detect mitigation actions tasks.
iot.list-dimensions: List the set of dimensions that are defined for your AWS account.
iot.list-domain-configurations: Gets a list of domain configurations for the user. This list is sorted alphabetically by domain configuration name.
iot.list-job-executions-for-job: Lists the job executions for a job.
iot.list-job-executions-for-thing: Lists the job executions for the specified thing.
iot.list-mitigation-actions: Gets a list of all mitigation actions that match the specified filter criteria.
iot.list-outgoing-certificates: Lists certificates that are being transferred but not yet accepted.
iot.list-policy-principals: Lists the principals associated with the specified policy.
iot.list-policy-versions: Lists the versions of the specified policy and identifies the default version.
iot.list-principal-policies: Lists the policies attached to the specified principal. If you use an Cognito identity, the ID must be in AmazonCognito Identity format .
iot.list-principal-things: Lists the things associated with the specified principal. A principal can be X.509 certificates, IAM users, groups, and roles, Amazon Cognito identities or federated identities.
iot.list-provisioning-template-versions: A list of fleet provisioning template versions.
iot.list-provisioning-templates: Lists the fleet provisioning templates in your AWS account.
iot.list-role-aliases: Lists the role aliases registered in your account.
iot.list-scheduled-audits: Lists all of your scheduled audits.
iot.list-security-profiles: Lists the Device Defender security profiles you've created. You can filter security profiles by dimension or custom metric.
iot.list-security-profiles-for-target: Lists the Device Defender security profiles attached to a target (thing group).
iot.list-streams: Lists all of the streams in your AWS account.
iot.list-tags-for-resource: Lists the tags (metadata) you have assigned to the resource.
iot.list-targets-for-policy: List targets for the specified policy.
iot.list-targets-for-security-profile: Lists the targets (thing groups) associated with a given Device Defender security profile.
iot.list-thing-groups: List the thing groups in your account.
iot.list-thing-groups-for-thing: List the thing groups to which the specified thing belongs.
iot.list-thing-principals: Lists the principals associated with the specified thing. A principal can be X.509 certificates, IAM users, groups, and roles, Amazon Cognito identities or federated identities.
iot.list-thing-registration-task-reports: Information about the thing registration tasks.
iot.list-things: Lists your things. Use the attributeName and attributeValue parameters to filter your things. For example, calling ListThings with attributeName=Color and attributeValue=Red retrieves all things in the registry that contain an attribute Color with the value Red .
iot.list-things-in-billing-group: Lists the things you have added to the given billing group.
iot.list-things-in-thing-group: Lists the things in the specified group.
iot.list-topic-rule-destinations: Lists all the topic rule destinations in your AWS account.
iot.list-topic-rules: Lists the rules for the specific topic.
iot.list-violation-events: Lists the Device Defender security profile violations discovered during the given time period. You can use filters to limit the results to those alerts issued for a particular security profile, behavior, or thing (device).
iot.register-ca-certificate: Registers a CA certificate with AWS IoT. This CA certificate can then be used to sign device certificates, which can be then registered with AWS IoT. You can register up to 10 CA certificates per AWS account that have the same subject field. This enables you to have up to 10 certificate authorities sign your device certificates. If you have more than one CA certificate registered, make sure you pass the CA certificate when you register your device certificates with the RegisterCertificate API.
iot.register-certificate: Registers a device certificate with AWS IoT. If you have more than one CA certificate that has the same subject field, you must specify the CA certificate that was used to sign the device certificate being registered.
iot.register-certificate-without-ca: Register a certificate that does not have a certificate authority (CA).
iot.register-thing: Provisions a thing in the device registry. RegisterThing calls other AWS IoT control plane APIs. These calls might exceed your account level AWS IoT Throttling Limits and cause throttle errors. Please contact AWS Customer Support to raise your throttling limits if necessary.
iot.reject-certificate-transfer: Rejects a pending certificate transfer. After AWS IoT rejects a certificate transfer, the certificate status changes from PENDING_TRANSFER to INACTIVE .
iot.remove-thing-from-billing-group: Removes the given thing from the billing group.
iot.remove-thing-from-thing-group: Remove the specified thing from the specified group.
iot.replace-topic-rule: Replaces the rule. You must specify all parameters for the new rule. Creating rules is an administrator-level action. Any user who has permission to create rules will be able to access data processed by the rule.
iot.set-default-authorizer: Sets the default authorizer. This will be used if a websocket connection is made without specifying an authorizer.
iot.set-default-policy-version: Sets the specified version of the specified policy as the policy's default (operative) version. This action affects all certificates to which the policy is attached. To list the principals the policy is attached to, use the ListPrincipalPolicy API.
iot.set-v2-logging-options: Sets the logging options for the V2 logging service.
iot.start-audit-mitigation-actions-task: Starts a task that applies a set of mitigation actions to the specified target.
iot.start-detect-mitigation-actions-task: Starts a Device Defender ML Detect mitigation actions task.
iot.start-on-demand-audit-task: Starts an on-demand Device Defender audit.
iot.start-thing-registration-task: Creates a bulk thing provisioning task.
iot.stop-thing-registration-task: Cancels a bulk thing provisioning task.
iot.tag-resource: Adds to or modifies the tags of the given resource. Tags are metadata which can be used to manage a resource.
iot.test-authorization: Tests if a specified principal is authorized to perform an AWS IoT action on a specified resource. Use this to test and debug the authorization behavior of devices that connect to the AWS IoT device gateway.
iot.test-invoke-authorizer: Tests a custom authorization behavior by invoking a specified custom authorizer. Use this to test and debug the custom authorization behavior of devices that connect to the AWS IoT device gateway.
iot.transfer-certificate: Transfers the specified certificate to the specified AWS account.
iot.untag-resource: Removes the given tags (metadata) from the resource.
iot.update-account-audit-configuration: Configures or reconfigures the Device Defender audit settings for this account. Settings include how audit notifications are sent and which audit checks are enabled or disabled.
iot.update-audit-suppression: Updates a Device Defender audit suppression.
iot.update-billing-group: Updates information about the billing group.
iot.update-certificate: Updates the status of the specified certificate. This operation is idempotent.
iot.update-custom-metric: Updates a Device Defender detect custom metric.
iot.update-dimension: Updates the definition for a dimension. You cannot change the type of a dimension after it is created (you can delete it and recreate it).
iot.update-domain-configuration: Updates values stored in the domain configuration. Domain configurations for default endpoints can't be updated.
iot.update-job: Updates supported fields of the specified job.
iot.update-mitigation-action: Updates the definition for the specified mitigation action.
iot.update-scheduled-audit: Updates a scheduled audit, including which checks are performed and how often the audit takes place.
iot.update-security-profile: Updates a Device Defender security profile.
iot.update-stream: Updates an existing stream. The stream version will be incremented by one.
iot.update-thing: Updates the data for a thing.
iot.update-thing-groups-for-thing: Updates the groups to which the thing belongs.
iot.update-topic-rule-destination: Updates a topic rule destination. You use this to change the status, endpoint URL, or confirmation URL of the destination.
iot.validate-security-profile-behaviors: Validates a Device Defender security profile behaviors specification.

iot-data.delete-thing-shadow: Deletes the shadow for the specified thing.
iot-data.get-thing-shadow: Gets the shadow for the specified thing.
iot-data.list-named-shadows-for-thing: Lists the shadows for the specified thing.
iot-data.update-thing-shadow: Updates the shadow for the specified thing.

iot-jobs-data.describe-job-execution: Gets details of a job execution.
iot-jobs-data.get-pending-job-executions: Gets the list of all jobs for a thing that are not in a terminal status.
iot-jobs-data.start-next-pending-job-execution: Gets and starts the next pending (status IN_PROGRESS or QUEUED) job execution for a thing.
iot-jobs-data.update-job-execution: Updates the status of a job execution.

iot1click-devices.claim-devices-by-claim-code: Adds device(s) to your account (i.e., claim one or more devices) if and only if you received a claim code with the device(s).
iot1click-devices.describe-device: Given a device ID, returns a DescribeDeviceResponse object describing the details of the device.
iot1click-devices.finalize-device-claim: Given a device ID, finalizes the claim request for the associated device.
iot1click-devices.get-device-methods: Given a device ID, returns the invokable methods associated with the device.
iot1click-devices.initiate-device-claim: Given a device ID, initiates a claim request for the associated device.
iot1click-devices.invoke-device-method: Given a device ID, issues a request to invoke a named device method (with possible parameters). See the "Example POST" code snippet below.
iot1click-devices.list-device-events: Using a device ID, returns a DeviceEventsResponse object containing an array of events for the device.
iot1click-devices.list-devices: Lists the 1-Click compatible devices associated with your AWS account.
iot1click-devices.list-tags-for-resource: Lists the tags associated with the specified resource ARN.
iot1click-devices.tag-resource: Adds or updates the tags associated with the resource ARN. See AWS IoT 1-Click Service Limits for the maximum number of tags allowed per resource.
iot1click-devices.unclaim-device: Disassociates a device from your AWS account using its device ID.
iot1click-devices.untag-resource: Using tag keys, deletes the tags (key/value pairs) associated with the specified resource ARN.
iot1click-devices.update-device-state: Using a Boolean value (true or false), this operation enables or disables the device given a device ID.

iot1click-projects.associate-device-with-placement: Associates a physical device with a placement.
iot1click-projects.create-project: Creates an empty project with a placement template. A project contains zero or more placements that adhere to the placement template defined in the project.
iot1click-projects.delete-placement: Deletes a placement. To delete a placement, it must not have any devices associated with it.
iot1click-projects.delete-project: Deletes a project. To delete a project, it must not have any placements associated with it.
iot1click-projects.describe-placement: Describes a placement in a project.
iot1click-projects.describe-project: Returns an object describing a project.
iot1click-projects.disassociate-device-from-placement: Removes a physical device from a placement.
iot1click-projects.get-devices-in-placement: Returns an object enumerating the devices in a placement.
iot1click-projects.list-placements: Lists the placement(s) of a project.
iot1click-projects.list-projects: Lists the AWS IoT 1-Click project(s) associated with your AWS account and region.
iot1click-projects.list-tags-for-resource: Lists the tags (metadata key/value pairs) which you have assigned to the resource.
iot1click-projects.tag-resource: Creates or modifies tags for a resource. Tags are key/value pairs (metadata) that can be used to manage a resource. For more information, see AWS Tagging Strategies .
iot1click-projects.untag-resource: Removes one or more tags (metadata key/value pairs) from a resource.
iot1click-projects.update-placement: Updates a placement with the given attributes. To clear an attribute, pass an empty value (i.e., "").
iot1click-projects.update-project: Updates a project associated with your AWS account and region. With the exception of device template names, you can pass just the values that need to be updated because the update request will change only the values that are provided. To clear a value, pass the empty string (i.e., "" ).

iotanalytics.cancel-pipeline-reprocessing: Cancels the reprocessing of data through the pipeline.
iotanalytics.create-channel: Creates a channel. A channel collects data from an MQTT topic and archives the raw, unprocessed messages before publishing the data to a pipeline.
iotanalytics.create-dataset: Creates a dataset. A dataset stores data retrieved from a data store by applying a queryAction (a SQL query) or a containerAction (executing a containerized application). This operation creates the skeleton of a dataset. The dataset can be populated manually by calling CreateDatasetContent or automatically according to a trigger you specify.
iotanalytics.create-dataset-content: Creates the content of a data set by applying a queryAction (a SQL query) or a containerAction (executing a containerized application).
iotanalytics.create-datastore: Creates a data store, which is a repository for messages.
iotanalytics.create-pipeline: Creates a pipeline. A pipeline consumes messages from a channel and allows you to process the messages before storing them in a data store. You must specify both a channel and a datastore activity and, optionally, as many as 23 additional activities in the pipelineActivities array.
iotanalytics.delete-dataset-content: Deletes the content of the specified dataset.
iotanalytics.describe-datastore: Retrieves information about a data store.
iotanalytics.describe-logging-options: Retrieves the current settings of the AWS IoT Analytics logging options.
iotanalytics.get-dataset-content: Retrieves the contents of a data set as presigned URIs.
iotanalytics.list-dataset-contents: Lists information about data set contents that have been created.
iotanalytics.list-datastores: Retrieves a list of data stores.
iotanalytics.list-tags-for-resource: Lists the tags (metadata) that you have assigned to the resource.
iotanalytics.put-logging-options: Sets or updates the AWS IoT Analytics logging options.
iotanalytics.run-pipeline-activity: Simulates the results of running a pipeline activity on a message payload.
iotanalytics.sample-channel-data: Retrieves a sample of messages from the specified channel ingested during the specified timeframe. Up to 10 messages can be retrieved.
iotanalytics.start-pipeline-reprocessing: Starts the reprocessing of raw message data through the pipeline.
iotanalytics.tag-resource: Adds to or modifies the tags of the given resource. Tags are metadata that can be used to manage a resource.
iotanalytics.untag-resource: Removes the given tags (metadata) from the resource.
iotanalytics.update-channel: Updates the settings of a channel.
iotanalytics.update-dataset: Updates the settings of a data set.
iotanalytics.update-datastore: Updates the settings of a data store.
iotanalytics.update-pipeline: Updates the settings of a pipeline. You must specify both a channel and a datastore activity and, optionally, as many as 23 additional activities in the pipelineActivities array.

iotdeviceadvisor.create-suite-definition: Creates a Device Advisor test suite.
iotdeviceadvisor.delete-suite-definition: Deletes a Device Advisor test suite.
iotdeviceadvisor.get-suite-definition: Gets information about a Device Advisor test suite.
iotdeviceadvisor.get-suite-run: Gets information about a Device Advisor test suite run.
iotdeviceadvisor.get-suite-run-report: Gets a report download link for a successful Device Advisor qualifying test suite run.
iotdeviceadvisor.list-suite-definitions: Lists the Device Advisor test suites you have created.
iotdeviceadvisor.list-suite-runs: Lists the runs of the specified Device Advisor test suite. You can list all runs of the test suite, or the runs of a specific version of the test suite.
iotdeviceadvisor.list-tags-for-resource: Lists the tags attached to an IoT Device Advisor resource.
iotdeviceadvisor.list-test-cases: Lists all the test cases in the test suite.
iotdeviceadvisor.start-suite-run: Starts a Device Advisor test suite run.
iotdeviceadvisor.tag-resource: Adds to and modifies existing tags of an IoT Device Advisor resource.
iotdeviceadvisor.untag-resource: Removes tags from an IoT Device Advisor resource.
iotdeviceadvisor.update-suite-definition: Updates a Device Advisor test suite.

iotevents.delete-detector-model: Deletes a detector model. Any active instances of the detector model are also deleted.
iotevents.describe-detector-model: Describes a detector model. If the version parameter is not specified, information about the latest version is returned.
iotevents.describe-detector-model-analysis: Retrieves execution information about a detector model analysis
iotevents.describe-logging-options: Retrieves the current settings of the AWS IoT Events logging options.
iotevents.get-detector-model-analysis-results: Retrieves one or more analysis results of the detector model.
iotevents.list-detector-model-versions: Lists all the versions of a detector model. Only the metadata associated with each detector model version is returned.
iotevents.list-detector-models: Lists the detector models you have created. Only the metadata associated with each detector model is returned.
iotevents.list-inputs: Lists the inputs you have created.
iotevents.list-tags-for-resource: Lists the tags (metadata) you have assigned to the resource.
iotevents.put-logging-options: Sets or updates the AWS IoT Events logging options.
iotevents.start-detector-model-analysis: Performs an analysis of your detector model. For more information, see Running detector model analyses in the AWS IoT Events Developer Guide .
iotevents.tag-resource: Adds to or modifies the tags of the given resource. Tags are metadata that can be used to manage a resource.
iotevents.untag-resource: Removes the given tags (metadata) from the resource.
iotevents.update-detector-model: Updates a detector model. Detectors (instances) spawned by the previous version are deleted and then re-created as new inputs arrive.

iotevents-data.batch-put-message: Sends a set of messages to the AWS IoT Events system. Each message payload is transformed into the input you specify ("inputName" ) and ingested into any detectors that monitor that input. If multiple messages are sent, the order in which the messages are processed isn't guaranteed. To guarantee ordering, you must send messages one at a time and wait for a successful response.
iotevents-data.batch-update-detector: Updates the state, variable values, and timer settings of one or more detectors (instances) of a specified detector model.
iotevents-data.describe-detector: Returns information about the specified detector (instance).
iotevents-data.list-detectors: Lists detectors (the instances of a detector model).

iotfleethub.create-application: Creates a Fleet Hub for AWS IoT Device Management web application.
iotfleethub.delete-application: Deletes a Fleet Hub for AWS IoT Device Management web application.
iotfleethub.describe-application: Gets information about a Fleet Hub for AWS IoT Device Management web application.
iotfleethub.list-applications: Gets a list of Fleet Hub for AWS IoT Device Management web applications for the current account.
iotfleethub.list-tags-for-resource: Lists the tags for the specified resource.
iotfleethub.tag-resource: Adds to or modifies the tags of the specified resource. Tags are metadata which can be used to manage a resource.
iotfleethub.untag-resource: Removes the specified tags (metadata) from the resource.
iotfleethub.update-application: Updates information about a Fleet Hub for a AWS IoT Device Management web application.

iotsecuretunneling.close-tunnel: Closes a tunnel identified by the unique tunnel id. When a CloseTunnel request is received, we close the WebSocket connections between the client and proxy server so no data can be transmitted.
iotsecuretunneling.describe-tunnel: Gets information about a tunnel identified by the unique tunnel id.
iotsecuretunneling.list-tags-for-resource: Lists the tags for the specified resource.
iotsecuretunneling.list-tunnels: List all tunnels for an AWS account. Tunnels are listed by creation time in descending order, newer tunnels will be listed before older tunnels.
iotsecuretunneling.open-tunnel: Creates a new tunnel, and returns two client access tokens for clients to use to connect to the AWS IoT Secure Tunneling proxy server.
iotsecuretunneling.untag-resource: Removes a tag from a resource.

iotsitewise.associate-assets: Associates a child asset with the given parent asset through a hierarchy defined in the parent asset's model. For more information, see Associating assets in the AWS IoT SiteWise User Guide .
iotsitewise.batch-associate-project-assets: Associates a group (batch) of assets with an AWS IoT SiteWise Monitor project.
iotsitewise.batch-disassociate-project-assets: Disassociates a group (batch) of assets from an AWS IoT SiteWise Monitor project.
iotsitewise.batch-put-asset-property-value: Sends a list of asset property values to AWS IoT SiteWise. Each value is a timestamp-quality-value (TQV) data point. For more information, see Ingesting data using the API in the AWS IoT SiteWise User Guide .
iotsitewise.create-access-policy: Creates an access policy that grants the specified identity (AWS SSO user, AWS SSO group, or IAM user) access to the specified AWS IoT SiteWise Monitor portal or project resource.
iotsitewise.create-asset: Creates an asset from an existing asset model. For more information, see Creating assets in the AWS IoT SiteWise User Guide .
iotsitewise.create-asset-model: Creates an asset model from specified property and hierarchy definitions. You create assets from asset models. With asset models, you can easily create assets of the same type that have standardized definitions. Each asset created from a model inherits the asset model's property and hierarchy definitions. For more information, see Defining asset models in the AWS IoT SiteWise User Guide .
iotsitewise.create-dashboard: Creates a dashboard in an AWS IoT SiteWise Monitor project.
iotsitewise.create-gateway: Creates a gateway, which is a virtual or edge device that delivers industrial data streams from local servers to AWS IoT SiteWise. For more information, see Ingesting data using a gateway in the AWS IoT SiteWise User Guide .
iotsitewise.create-portal: Creates a portal, which can contain projects and dashboards. AWS IoT SiteWise Monitor uses AWS SSO or IAM to authenticate portal users and manage user permissions.
iotsitewise.create-project: Creates a project in the specified portal.
iotsitewise.delete-access-policy: Deletes an access policy that grants the specified identity access to the specified AWS IoT SiteWise Monitor resource. You can use this operation to revoke access to an AWS IoT SiteWise Monitor resource.
iotsitewise.delete-asset: Deletes an asset. This action can't be undone. For more information, see Deleting assets and models in the AWS IoT SiteWise User Guide .
iotsitewise.delete-asset-model: Deletes an asset model. This action can't be undone. You must delete all assets created from an asset model before you can delete the model. Also, you can't delete an asset model if a parent asset model exists that contains a property formula expression that depends on the asset model that you want to delete. For more information, see Deleting assets and models in the AWS IoT SiteWise User Guide .
iotsitewise.delete-dashboard: Deletes a dashboard from AWS IoT SiteWise Monitor.
iotsitewise.delete-gateway: Deletes a gateway from AWS IoT SiteWise. When you delete a gateway, some of the gateway's files remain in your gateway's file system.
iotsitewise.delete-portal: Deletes a portal from AWS IoT SiteWise Monitor.
iotsitewise.delete-project: Deletes a project from AWS IoT SiteWise Monitor.
iotsitewise.describe-access-policy: Describes an access policy, which specifies an identity's access to an AWS IoT SiteWise Monitor portal or project.
iotsitewise.describe-asset-model: Retrieves information about an asset model.
iotsitewise.describe-asset-property: Retrieves information about an asset property.
iotsitewise.describe-default-encryption-configuratio: Retrieves information about the default encryption configuration for the AWS account in the default or specified region. For more information, see Key management in the AWS IoT SiteWise User Guide .
iotsitewise.describe-gateway-capability-configuratio: Retrieves information about a gateway capability configuration. Each gateway capability defines data sources for a gateway. A capability configuration can contain multiple data source configurations. If you define OPC-UA sources for a gateway in the AWS IoT SiteWise console, all of your OPC-UA sources are stored in one capability configuration. To list all capability configurations for a gateway, use DescribeGateway .
iotsitewise.describe-logging-options: Retrieves the current AWS IoT SiteWise logging options.
iotsitewise.disassociate-assets: Disassociates a child asset from the given parent asset through a hierarchy defined in the parent asset's model.
iotsitewise.get-asset-property-aggregates: Gets aggregated values for an asset property. For more information, see Querying aggregates in the AWS IoT SiteWise User Guide .
iotsitewise.get-asset-property-value: Gets an asset property's current value. For more information, see Querying current values in the AWS IoT SiteWise User Guide .
iotsitewise.get-asset-property-value-history: Gets the history of an asset property's values. For more information, see Querying historical values in the AWS IoT SiteWise User Guide .
iotsitewise.list-access-policies: Retrieves a paginated list of access policies for an identity (an AWS SSO user, an AWS SSO group, or an IAM user) or an AWS IoT SiteWise Monitor resource (a portal or project).
iotsitewise.list-asset-models: Retrieves a paginated list of summaries of all asset models.
iotsitewise.list-asset-relationships: Retrieves a paginated list of asset relationships for an asset. You can use this operation to identify an asset's root asset and all associated assets between that asset and its root.
iotsitewise.list-assets: Retrieves a paginated list of asset summaries.
iotsitewise.list-associated-assets: Retrieves a paginated list of associated assets.
iotsitewise.list-dashboards: Retrieves a paginated list of dashboards for an AWS IoT SiteWise Monitor project.
iotsitewise.list-gateways: Retrieves a paginated list of gateways.
iotsitewise.list-portals: Retrieves a paginated list of AWS IoT SiteWise Monitor portals.
iotsitewise.list-project-assets: Retrieves a paginated list of assets associated with an AWS IoT SiteWise Monitor project.
iotsitewise.list-projects: Retrieves a paginated list of projects for an AWS IoT SiteWise Monitor portal.
iotsitewise.list-tags-for-resource: Retrieves the list of tags for an AWS IoT SiteWise resource.
iotsitewise.put-default-encryption-configuration: Sets the default encryption configuration for the AWS account. For more information, see Key management in the AWS IoT SiteWise User Guide .
iotsitewise.put-logging-options: Sets logging options for AWS IoT SiteWise.
iotsitewise.tag-resource: Adds tags to an AWS IoT SiteWise resource. If a tag already exists for the resource, this operation updates the tag's value.
iotsitewise.untag-resource: Removes a tag from an AWS IoT SiteWise resource.
iotsitewise.update-access-policy: Updates an existing access policy that specifies an identity's access to an AWS IoT SiteWise Monitor portal or project resource.
iotsitewise.update-asset: Updates an asset's name. For more information, see Updating assets and models in the AWS IoT SiteWise User Guide .
iotsitewise.update-asset-model: Updates an asset model and all of the assets that were created from the model. Each asset created from the model inherits the updated asset model's property and hierarchy definitions. For more information, see Updating assets and models in the AWS IoT SiteWise User Guide .
iotsitewise.update-asset-property: Updates an asset property's alias and notification state.
iotsitewise.update-dashboard: Updates an AWS IoT SiteWise Monitor dashboard.
iotsitewise.update-gateway-capability-configuration: Updates a gateway capability configuration or defines a new capability configuration. Each gateway capability defines data sources for a gateway. A capability configuration can contain multiple data source configurations. If you define OPC-UA sources for a gateway in the AWS IoT SiteWise console, all of your OPC-UA sources are stored in one capability configuration. To list all capability configurations for a gateway, use DescribeGateway .
iotsitewise.update-portal: Updates an AWS IoT SiteWise Monitor portal.
iotsitewise.update-project: Updates an AWS IoT SiteWise Monitor project.
iotsitewise.wait asset-active: Wait until JMESPath query assetStatus.state returns ACTIVE when polling with describe-asset. It will poll every 3 seconds until a successful state has been reached. This will exit with a return code of 255 after 20 failed checks.
iotsitewise.wait asset-model-active: Wait until JMESPath query assetModelStatus.state returns ACTIVE when polling with describe-asset-model. It will poll every 3 seconds until a successful state has been reached. This will exit with a return code of 255 after 20 failed checks.
iotsitewise.wait asset-model-not-exists: Wait until ResourceNotFoundException is thrown when polling with describe-asset-model. It will poll every 3 seconds until a successful state has been reached. This will exit with a return code of 255 after 20 failed checks.
iotsitewise.wait asset-not-exists: Wait until ResourceNotFoundException is thrown when polling with describe-asset. It will poll every 3 seconds until a successful state has been reached. This will exit with a return code of 255 after 20 failed checks.
iotsitewise.wait portal-active: Wait until JMESPath query portalStatus.state returns ACTIVE when polling with describe-portal. It will poll every 3 seconds until a successful state has been reached. This will exit with a return code of 255 after 20 failed checks.
iotsitewise.wait portal-not-exists: Wait until ResourceNotFoundException is thrown when polling with describe-portal. It will poll every 3 seconds until a successful state has been reached. This will exit with a return code of 255 after 20 failed checks.

iotthingsgraph.associate-entity-to-thing: Associates a device with a concrete thing that is in the user's registry.
iotthingsgraph.create-flow-template: Creates a workflow template. Workflows can be created only in the user's namespace. (The public namespace contains only entities.) The workflow can contain only entities in the specified namespace. The workflow is validated against the entities in the latest version of the user's namespace unless another namespace version is specified in the request.
iotthingsgraph.create-system-template: Creates a system. The system is validated against the entities in the latest version of the user's namespace unless another namespace version is specified in the request.
iotthingsgraph.delete-flow-template: Deletes a workflow. Any new system or deployment that contains this workflow will fail to update or deploy. Existing deployments that contain the workflow will continue to run (since they use a snapshot of the workflow taken at the time of deployment).
iotthingsgraph.delete-namespace: Deletes the specified namespace. This action deletes all of the entities in the namespace. Delete the systems and flows that use entities in the namespace before performing this action.
iotthingsgraph.delete-system-instance: Deletes a system instance. Only system instances that have never been deployed, or that have been undeployed can be deleted.
iotthingsgraph.delete-system-template: Deletes a system. New deployments can't contain the system after its deletion. Existing deployments that contain the system will continue to work because they use a snapshot of the system that is taken when it is deployed.
iotthingsgraph.deploy-system-instance: Deploys the system instance to the target specified in CreateSystemInstance .
iotthingsgraph.deprecate-flow-template: Deprecates the specified workflow. This action marks the workflow for deletion. Deprecated flows can't be deployed, but existing deployments will continue to run.
iotthingsgraph.describe-namespace: Gets the latest version of the user's namespace and the public version that it is tracking.
iotthingsgraph.dissociate-entity-from-thing: Dissociates a device entity from a concrete thing. The action takes only the type of the entity that you need to dissociate because only one entity of a particular type can be associated with a thing.
iotthingsgraph.get-entities: Gets definitions of the specified entities. Uses the latest version of the user's namespace by default. This API returns the following TDM entities.
iotthingsgraph.get-flow-template: Gets the latest version of the DefinitionDocument and FlowTemplateSummary for the specified workflow.
iotthingsgraph.get-flow-template-revisions: Gets revisions of the specified workflow. Only the last 100 revisions are stored. If the workflow has been deprecated, this action will return revisions that occurred before the deprecation. This action won't work for workflows that have been deleted.
iotthingsgraph.get-namespace-deletion-status: Gets the status of a namespace deletion task.
iotthingsgraph.get-system-template-revisions: Gets revisions made to the specified system template. Only the previous 100 revisions are stored. If the system has been deprecated, this action will return the revisions that occurred before its deprecation. This action won't work with systems that have been deleted.
iotthingsgraph.get-upload-status: Gets the status of the specified upload.
iotthingsgraph.list-flow-execution-messages: Returns a list of objects that contain information about events in a flow execution.
iotthingsgraph.list-tags-for-resource: Lists all tags on an AWS IoT Things Graph resource.
iotthingsgraph.search-entities: Searches for entities of the specified type. You can search for entities in your namespace and the public namespace that you're tracking.
iotthingsgraph.search-flow-executions: Searches for AWS IoT Things Graph workflow execution instances.
iotthingsgraph.search-flow-templates: Searches for summary information about workflows.
iotthingsgraph.search-system-instances: Searches for system instances in the user's account.
iotthingsgraph.search-system-templates: Searches for summary information about systems in the user's account. You can filter by the ID of a workflow to return only systems that use the specified workflow.
iotthingsgraph.search-things: Searches for things associated with the specified entity. You can search by both device and device model.
iotthingsgraph.tag-resource: Creates a tag for the specified resource.
iotthingsgraph.undeploy-system-instance: Removes a system instance from its target (Cloud or Greengrass).
iotthingsgraph.untag-resource: Removes a tag from the specified resource.
iotthingsgraph.update-flow-template: Updates the specified workflow. All deployed systems and system instances that use the workflow will see the changes in the flow when it is redeployed. If you don't want this behavior, copy the workflow (creating a new workflow with a different ID), and update the copy. The workflow can contain only entities in the specified namespace.
iotthingsgraph.update-system-template: Updates the specified system. You don't need to run this action after updating a workflow. Any deployment that uses the system will see the changes in the system when it is redeployed.
iotthingsgraph.upload-entity-definitions: Asynchronously uploads one or more entity definitions to the user's namespace. The document parameter is required if syncWithPublicNamespace and deleteExistingEntites are false. If the syncWithPublicNamespace parameter is set to true , the user's namespace will synchronize with the latest version of the public namespace. If deprecateExistingEntities is set to true, all entities in the latest version will be deleted before the new DefinitionDocument is uploaded.

iotwireless.associate-aws-account-with-partner-accou: Associates a partner account with your AWS account.
iotwireless.associate-wireless-device-with-thing: Associates a wireless device with a thing.
iotwireless.associate-wireless-gateway-with-certific: Associates a wireless gateway with a certificate.
iotwireless.associate-wireless-gateway-with-thing: Associates a wireless gateway with a thing.
iotwireless.create-destination: Creates a new destination that maps a device message to an AWS IoT rule.
iotwireless.create-wireless-gateway-task: Creates a task for a wireless gateway.
iotwireless.delete-wireless-gateway-task-definition: Deletes a wireless gateway task definition. Deleting this task definition does not affect tasks that are currently in progress.
iotwireless.disassociate-aws-account-from-partner-ac: Disassociates your AWS account from a partner account. If PartnerAccountId and PartnerType are null , disassociates your AWS account from all partner accounts.
iotwireless.disassociate-wireless-device-from-thing: Disassociates a wireless device from its currently associated thing.
iotwireless.disassociate-wireless-gateway-from-certi: Disassociates a wireless gateway from its currently associated certificate.
iotwireless.disassociate-wireless-gateway-from-thing: Disassociates a wireless gateway from its currently associated thing.
iotwireless.get-device-profile: Gets information about a device profile.
iotwireless.get-partner-account: Gets information about a partner account. If PartnerAccountId and PartnerType are null , returns all partner accounts.
iotwireless.get-service-endpoint: Gets the account-specific endpoint for Configuration and Update Server (CUPS) protocol or LoRaWAN Network Server (LNS) connections.
iotwireless.get-service-profile: Gets information about a service profile.
iotwireless.get-wireless-device: Gets information about a wireless device.
iotwireless.get-wireless-device-statistics: Gets operating information about a wireless device.
iotwireless.get-wireless-gateway: Gets information about a wireless gateway.
iotwireless.get-wireless-gateway-certificate: Gets the ID of the certificate that is currently associated with a wireless gateway.
iotwireless.get-wireless-gateway-firmware-informatio: Gets the firmware version and other information about a wireless gateway.
iotwireless.get-wireless-gateway-statistics: Gets operating information about a wireless gateway.
iotwireless.get-wireless-gateway-task: Gets information about a wireless gateway task.
iotwireless.get-wireless-gateway-task-definition: Gets information about a wireless gateway task definition.
iotwireless.list-destinations: Lists the destinations registered to your AWS account.
iotwireless.list-device-profiles: Lists the device profiles registered to your AWS account.
iotwireless.list-partner-accounts: Lists the partner accounts associated with your AWS account.
iotwireless.list-service-profiles: Lists the service profiles registered to your AWS account.
iotwireless.list-tags-for-resource: Lists the tags (metadata) you have assigned to the resource.
iotwireless.list-wireless-devices: Lists the wireless devices registered to your AWS account.
iotwireless.list-wireless-gateway-task-definitions: List the wireless gateway tasks definitions registered to your AWS account.
iotwireless.list-wireless-gateways: Lists the wireless gateways registered to your AWS account.
iotwireless.send-data-to-wireless-device: Sends a decrypted application data frame to a device.
iotwireless.tag-resource: Adds a tag to a resource.
iotwireless.test-wireless-device: Simulates a provisioned device by sending an uplink data payload of Hello .
iotwireless.untag-resource: Removes one or more tags from a resource.
iotwireless.update-partner-account: Updates properties of a partner account.
iotwireless.update-wireless-device: Updates properties of a wireless device.
iotwireless.update-wireless-gateway: Updates properties of a wireless gateway.

ivs.batch-get-channel: Performs  GetChannel on multiple ARNs simultaneously.
ivs.batch-get-stream-key: Performs  GetStreamKey on multiple ARNs simultaneously.
ivs.create-channel: Creates a new channel and an associated stream key to start streaming.
ivs.create-stream-key: Creates a stream key, used to initiate a stream, for the specified channel ARN.
ivs.delete-channel: Deletes the specified channel and its associated stream keys.
ivs.delete-playback-key-pair: Deletes a specified authorization key pair. This invalidates future viewer tokens generated using the key pair’s privateKey .
ivs.delete-stream-key: Deletes the stream key for the specified ARN, so it can no longer be used to stream.
ivs.get-channel: Gets the channel configuration for the specified channel ARN. See also  BatchGetChannel .
ivs.get-playback-key-pair: Gets a specified playback authorization key pair and returns the arn and fingerprint . The privateKey held by the caller can be used to generate viewer authorization tokens, to grant viewers access to authorized channels.
ivs.get-stream: Gets information about the active (live) stream on a specified channel.
ivs.get-stream-key: Gets stream-key information for a specified ARN.
ivs.import-playback-key-pair: Imports the public portion of a new key pair and returns its arn and fingerprint . The privateKey can then be used to generate viewer authorization tokens, to grant viewers access to authorized channels.
ivs.list-channels: Gets summary information about all channels in your account, in the AWS region where the API request is processed. This list can be filtered to match a specified string.
ivs.list-playback-key-pairs: Gets summary information about playback key pairs.
ivs.list-stream-keys: Gets summary information about stream keys for the specified channel.
ivs.list-streams: Gets summary information about live streams in your account, in the AWS region where the API request is processed.
ivs.list-tags-for-resource: Gets information about AWS tags for the specified ARN.
ivs.put-metadata: Inserts metadata into an RTMPS stream for the specified channel. A maximum of 5 requests per second per channel is allowed, each with a maximum 1KB payload.
ivs.stop-stream: Disconnects the incoming RTMPS stream for the specified channel. Can be used in conjunction with  DeleteStreamKey to prevent further streaming to a channel.
ivs.tag-resource: Adds or updates tags for the AWS resource with the specified ARN.
ivs.untag-resource: Removes tags from the resource with the specified ARN.
ivs.update-channel: Updates a channel's configuration. This does not affect an ongoing stream of this channel. You must stop and restart the stream for the changes to take effect.

kafka.batch-associate-scram-secret: Associates one or more Scram Secrets with an Amazon MSK cluster.
kafka.batch-disassociate-scram-secret: Disassociates one or more Scram Secrets from an Amazon MSK cluster.
kafka.delete-cluster: Deletes the MSK cluster specified by the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) in the request.
kafka.describe-cluster: Returns a description of the MSK cluster whose Amazon Resource Name (ARN) is specified in the request.
kafka.describe-cluster-operation: Returns a description of the cluster operation specified by the ARN.
kafka.describe-configuration: Returns a description of this MSK configuration.
kafka.describe-configuration-revision: Returns a description of this revision of the configuration.
kafka.get-bootstrap-brokers: A list of brokers that a client application can use to bootstrap.
kafka.get-compatible-kafka-versions: Gets the Apache Kafka versions to which you can update the MSK cluster.
kafka.list-cluster-operations: Returns a list of all the operations that have been performed on the specified MSK cluster.
kafka.list-clusters: Returns a list of all the MSK clusters in the current Region.
kafka.list-configuration-revisions: Returns a list of all the MSK configurations in this Region.
kafka.list-configurations: Returns a list of all the MSK configurations in this Region.
kafka.list-kafka-versions: Returns a list of Kafka versions.
kafka.list-nodes: Returns a list of the broker nodes in the cluster.
kafka.list-scram-secrets: Returns a list of the Scram Secrets associated with an Amazon MSK cluster.
kafka.list-tags-for-resource: Returns a list of the tags associated with the specified resource.
kafka.tag-resource: Adds tags to the specified MSK resource.
kafka.untag-resource: Removes the tags associated with the keys that are provided in the query.
kafka.update-broker-count: Updates the number of broker nodes in the cluster.
kafka.update-broker-storage: Updates the EBS storage associated with MSK brokers.
kafka.update-cluster-configuration: Updates the cluster with the configuration that is specified in the request body.
kafka.update-cluster-kafka-version: Updates the Apache Kafka version for the cluster.
kafka.update-monitoring: Updates the monitoring settings for the cluster. You can use this operation to specify which Apache Kafka metrics you want Amazon MSK to send to Amazon CloudWatch. You can also specify settings for open monitoring with Prometheus.

kendra.batch-delete-document: Removes one or more documents from an index. The documents must have been added with the  BatchPutDocument operation.
kendra.batch-put-document: Adds one or more documents to an index.
kendra.create-data-source: Creates a data source that you use to with an Amazon Kendra index.
kendra.create-faq: Creates an new set of frequently asked question (FAQ) questions and answers.
kendra.create-index: Creates a new Amazon Kendra index. Index creation is an asynchronous operation. To determine if index creation has completed, check the Status field returned from a call to . The Status field is set to ACTIVE when the index is ready to use.
kendra.create-thesaurus: Creates a thesaurus for an index. The thesaurus contains a list of synonyms in Solr format.
kendra.delete-data-source: Deletes an Amazon Kendra data source. An exception is not thrown if the data source is already being deleted. While the data source is being deleted, the Status field returned by a call to the operation is set to DELETING . For more information, see Deleting Data Sources .
kendra.delete-faq: Removes an FAQ from an index.
kendra.delete-index: Deletes an existing Amazon Kendra index. An exception is not thrown if the index is already being deleted. While the index is being deleted, the Status field returned by a call to the  DescribeIndex operation is set to DELETING .
kendra.delete-thesaurus: Deletes an existing Amazon Kendra thesaurus.
kendra.describe-data-source: Gets information about a Amazon Kendra data source.
kendra.describe-faq: Gets information about an FAQ list.
kendra.describe-index: Describes an existing Amazon Kendra index
kendra.describe-thesaurus: Describes an existing Amazon Kendra thesaurus.
kendra.list-data-source-sync-jobs: Gets statistics about synchronizing Amazon Kendra with a data source.
kendra.list-data-sources: Lists the data sources that you have created.
kendra.list-faqs: Gets a list of FAQ lists associated with an index.
kendra.list-indices: Lists the Amazon Kendra indexes that you have created.
kendra.list-tags-for-resource: Gets a list of tags associated with a specified resource. Indexes, FAQs, and data sources can have tags associated with them.
kendra.list-thesauri: Lists the Amazon Kendra thesauri associated with an index.
kendra.query: Searches an active index. Use this API to search your documents using query. The Query operation enables to do faceted search and to filter results based on document attributes.
kendra.start-data-source-sync-job: Starts a synchronization job for a data source. If a synchronization job is already in progress, Amazon Kendra returns a ResourceInUseException exception.
kendra.stop-data-source-sync-job: Stops a running synchronization job. You can't stop a scheduled synchronization job.
kendra.submit-feedback: Enables you to provide feedback to Amazon Kendra to improve the performance of the service.
kendra.tag-resource: Adds the specified tag to the specified index, FAQ, or data source resource. If the tag already exists, the existing value is replaced with the new value.
kendra.untag-resource: Removes a tag from an index, FAQ, or a data source.
kendra.update-data-source: Updates an existing Amazon Kendra data source.
kendra.update-index: Updates an existing Amazon Kendra index.
kendra.update-thesaurus: Updates a thesaurus file associated with an index.

kinesis.add-tags-to-stream: Adds or updates tags for the specified Kinesis data stream. Each time you invoke this operation, you can specify up to 10 tags. If you want to add more than 10 tags to your stream, you can invoke this operation multiple times. In total, each stream can have up to 50 tags.
kinesis.create-stream: Creates a Kinesis data stream. A stream captures and transports data records that are continuously emitted from different data sources or producers . Scale-out within a stream is explicitly supported by means of shards, which are uniquely identified groups of data records in a stream.
kinesis.decrease-stream-retention-period: Decreases the Kinesis data stream's retention period, which is the length of time data records are accessible after they are added to the stream. The minimum value of a stream's retention period is 24 hours.
kinesis.delete-stream: Deletes a Kinesis data stream and all its shards and data. You must shut down any applications that are operating on the stream before you delete the stream. If an application attempts to operate on a deleted stream, it receives the exception ResourceNotFoundException .
